author: By Reuters
title: Anger in Chile After Boy Is Shown Falling From Bridge During Police Clashes
description: Video of the teenager’s fall into a shallow river went viral in Chile, which was convulsed by unrest a year ago.
content: SANTIAGO — Security forces in Chile’s capital, Santiago, were accused of misconduct Friday after a video emerged showing a teenage boy falling from a bridge into a river during clashes with the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: What a $300,000 College Might Cost a $200,000 Family
description: More need-based financial aid is available for the affluent than you might expect.
content: College is so expensive that even the affluent can be considered needy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain and E.U. Enter Make-or-Break Phase for Brexit Deal by Year’s End
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the president of the European Commission agreed that the two sides shared enough common ground to aim for a final settlement.
content: LONDON — Britain’s lengthy divorce proceedings with the European Union entered a make-or-break phase on Saturday as Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the European Commission president agreed that the two sides shared enough common ground to aim for a final settlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Antonova
title: A Toxic Alien Is Taking Over Russia
description: The giant hogweed isn’t just an invasive plant. It’s a metaphor for what is happening to much of this country.
content: BALASHIKHA, Russia — Take any of the many highways out of the Russian capital and you can dissect the country’s strata like rings on a tree. Sentinel apartment towers replace the bustling illuminated center, then the belt of auto dealerships and box stores drifts by. Gradually, the landscape becomes sparse, with villages and towns sporadically punctuating the stretch of meadows and forests for thousands of miles in every direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Clinical Trials Hit by Ransomware Attack on Health Tech Firm
description: No patients were affected, but the incident was another reminder of the risks in the increasingly common assaults on computer networks.
content: A Philadelphia company that sells software used in hundreds of clinical trials, including the crash effort to develop tests, treatments and a vaccine for the coronavirus, was hit by a ransomware attack that has slowed some of those trials over the past two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Trump’s hospitalization starts to affect the campaign trail.
description: President Trump’s hospitalization has forced his campaign to cancel rallies in the battleground states of Florida and Wisconsin, compromising his ability to motivate supporters with just weeks until the Nov. 3 election.
content: President Trump’s hospitalization has forced his campaign to cancel rallies in the battleground states of Florida and Wisconsin, compromising his ability to motivate supporters with just weeks until the Nov. 3 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Trump’s Covid Treatments Are Aimed at Preventing Severe Illness
description: Outside experts pointed to the therapies as signs that the president’s health may not be as good as his doctors said. His age, weight and gender put him at high risk.
content: President Trump will stay at Walter Reed military hospital for an indefinite number of days, his doctor said on Saturday, undergoing a five-day antiviral drug regimen for Covid-19 that indicated his condition might be more serious than had been publicly disclosed. On Thursday, he received another therapy that is still in early phases of testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bob Gibson, Feared Flamethrower for the Cardinals, Dies at 84
description: Gibson, who won two Cy Young Awards and threw 56 career shutouts, was one of baseball’s most dominating and intimidating pitchers.
content: Bob Gibson, the St. Louis Cardinals’ Hall of Fame right-hander who became one of baseball’s most dominating pitchers, winning 251 games in 17 seasons with an intimidating fastball and an attitude to match, died on Friday in Omaha. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Floodgates in Venice Work in First Major Test
description: The fiercely contested floodgate system was used to stop a high tide from flooding Venice’s fragile streets. The system held, but will it work as the climate worsens?
content: ROME — After decades of bureaucratic delays, corruption and resistance from environmental groups, sea walls designed to defend Venice from “acqua alta,” or high water, went up on Saturday, testing their ability to battle the city’s increasingly menacing floods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Arctic Expedition’s Dress Code Raises Concerns About Sexism in Science
description: The scientific institute leading the trip denied that its policy had been applied to a specific sex, saying, “Women and men participate in our polar expeditions as equals.”
content: LONDON — The dress-code policy of a prominent polar research institute in Germany has provoked criticism and outrage after it was recently made public, with some experts saying it underscored the problem of sexism in the sciences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Sofia Kenin’s Knack for Rebounds Is Being Tested at the French Open. And in 2020.
description: The coronavirus pandemic took away a window of opportunity for Sofia Kenin after she won the Australian Open in January. But she’s still motivated.
content: It takes grit for a tennis player at any level to bounce back quickly from losing 6-0, 6-0.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Poll Finds Voters in Two Crucial States Repelled by Trump’s Debate Behavior
description: Biden is ahead by seven points in Pennsylvania and five points in Florida, according to the Times/Siena survey.
content: By overwhelming margins, voters in Pennsylvania and Florida were repelled by President Trump’s conduct in the first general election debate, according to New York Times/Siena College surveys, as Joseph R. Biden Jr. maintained a lead in the two largest battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Contact Tracing, Key to Reining In the Virus, Falls Flat in the West
description: Tracing is seen as a vital tool to avoid lockdowns and open economies, but that requires a robust system, widespread rapid testing and public trust. All are lacking in the West.
content: LONDON — As the coronavirus stampeded across Europe and the United States this spring, governments made their depleted citizens a tantalizing promise: Soon, legions of disease detectives would hunt down anyone exposed to the virus, confining them to their homes and letting everyone else get on with their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India’s Covid-19 Death Toll Passes 100,000
description: Only the United States and Brazil have reported more deaths from the coronavirus. Despite its climbing numbers, India plans to lift more restrictions.
content: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — More than 100,000 people in India have died from the coronavirus, the government said on Saturday, even as officials plan to lift more restrictions in hopes of reviving the crippled economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Nicholas Fandos, Catie Edmondson, Lisa Lerer, Lauren Wolfe and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Two senators on the Judiciary Committee test positive, raising questions about the timing of Barrett’s confirmation hearings.
description: Two Republican senators on the pivotal Judiciary Committee have tested positive for the coronavirus after attending White House events last week announcing Mr. Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, throwing the future of her Supreme Court confirmation hearings into question.
content: Two Republican senators on the pivotal Judiciary Committee have tested positive for the coronavirus after attending White House events last week announcing Mr. Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, throwing the future of her Supreme Court confirmation hearings into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Trip Gabriel
title: The President’s Illness Is Yet Another Dividing Line in the Trump Era
description: In a different moment, a stricken leader might have rallied people behind him. But President Trump’s health crisis is filtered through the partisan lenses that divide Americans on seemingly every issue.
content: PHOENIX — Soon after he woke up on Friday morning, Cruz Zepeda, a 54-year-old Trump supporter, received a text from a lifelong friend eager to share a sentiment he found on Twitter: “Looks like RBG successfully argued her first hearing with the Lord.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: They Cheered Trump in Minnesota, at the Last Big Rally Before His Virus Test
description: After President Trump tested positive, some Minnesota Republicans were undergoing tests, while others said they were unconcerned about potential risks.
content: The scene at the airport in Duluth, Minn., on Wednesday night was jubilant and carefree, despite the 40-degree temperatures, pelting rain and blustery wind blowing toward Lake Superior. A 3,000-person audience cheered for President Trump, who spoke for 45 minutes and tossed hats into the approving crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Mother’s Little Helper Is Back, and Daddy’s Partaking Too
description: After the kids go to bed, the grown-ups are drinking and smoking pot to distract themselves from the hellscape that is pandemic parenting.
content: 7:51 p.m.: It’s exactly 125 days tomorrow. I am pretg drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: How Many Lives Can a Fashion Brand Have?
description: Sonia Rykiel gets ready for yet another reinvention.
content: A little more than a year ago, the beloved French fashion house Sonia Rykiel — founded in 1968 by a flame-haired feminist to empower women, passed on to her daughter in 2007 and sold to Hong Kong investors in 2012 — went into liquidation. At the time, it appeared to be a sad denouement for the once-revolutionary ready-to-wear brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Some Insurers End Pandemic Waivers of Fees and Deductibles for Telehealth
description: The coronavirus outbreaks had prompted the nation’s largest insurers to stop charging co-pays or requiring deductibles for virtual visits, but some consumers will now have to pay those fees again.
content: Some people will have to start paying more out of their own pockets for telemedicine appointments, if their virtual visits with doctors are unrelated to Covid-19 and are needed to monitor conditions like diabetes or to check out sudden knee pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Democratic challenger in North Carolina’s Senate race apologizes for romantic texts to a woman who is not his wife.
description: Cal Cunningham, the Democratic former state senator and Iraq war veteran who is locked in a closely watched and tight race to unseat Senator Thom Tillis of North Carolina, a Republican, apologized on Saturday after a report that he had exchanged romantic text messages with a woman who is not his wife.
content: Cal Cunningham, the Democratic former state senator and Iraq war veteran who is locked in a closely watched and tight race to unseat Senator Thom Tillis of North Carolina, a Republican, apologized on Saturday after a report that he had exchanged romantic text messages with a woman who is not his wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Reality Bursts the Trumpworld Bubble
description: In a moment that feels biblical, the implacable virus has come to the president’s door.
content: WASHINGTON — Fate leads the willing, Seneca said, while the unwilling get dragged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Chris Christie, who helped Trump prepare for the debate, has the virus.
description: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who for several days this week helped the president prepare for the debate, said he has tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who for several days this week helped the president prepare for the debate, said he has tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: In Wake of Recent India-China Conflict, U.S. Sees Opportunity
description: India’s border dispute with China has accelerated its relations with the United States. Others worry that warming ties ignore India’s persecution of Muslims.
content: WASHINGTON — Weeks after India and China engaged in their deadliest border clash in decades, the sight of an American nuclear-powered aircraft carrier entering the Bay of Bengal drew attention across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: The Busy Week When the President Met the Virus
description: He disparaged masks, encouraged big campaign crowds and employed an often-unreliable test to keep him safe. All the while it turned out the virus was nearby.
content: WASHINGTON — Marine One, its engines roaring, was waiting on the South Lawn of the White House Thursday afternoon when President Trump walked out of the Oval Office, offering a brief wave but skipping his usual verbal combat with reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorothy J. Gentry
title: The Seattle Storm Have Even More Weapons Than You Think
description: The Storm are powered by big-name superstars, but other players like Jordin Canada and Alysha Clark have been crucial in Seattle’s run to the W.N.B.A. finals.
content: Sue Bird believes the Seattle Storm are the true definition of a team, achieving more than most by working together as a unit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Symptoms Described as ‘Very Concerning’ Even as Doctors Offer Rosier Picture
description: The president’s medical team refused to provide critical details and left open the impression that he was known to be sick a day earlier than previously reported, forcing them to backtrack later.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House offered a barrage of conflicting messages and contradictory accounts about President Trump’s health on Saturday as he remained hospitalized with the coronavirus for a second night and the outbreak spread to a wider swath of his aides and allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Virus Diagnosis and Secret Texts Upend a Critical Senate Race in a Single Night
description: The Senate race in North Carolina was engulfed in chaos after the incumbent tested positive for coronavirus and his challenger admitted to exchanging romantic texts with a woman who is not his wife.
content: WASHINGTON — Even for an election cycle defined by a relentless string of crises and chaos, the amount of time it took for the Senate race in North Carolina, which could determine which party controls the Senate, to fall into utter mayhem was something of a record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: The Fattest Bears in Alaska Want Your Vote
description: Each year, people vote for the heftiest brown bear at the Katmai National Park and Preserve during the Fat Bear Week contest.
content: Like a rite of fall, the Katmai National Park and Preserve in southern Alaska celebrates its fattest brown bears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Washington State Officials Hunt for Colony of ‘Murder Hornets’
description: The search has taken on particular urgency as the Asian giant hornets are about to enter their “slaughter phase,” during which they kill bees by decapitating them.
content: Philip Bovenkamp knew he might have something unusual on his property near Blaine, Wash., when he spotted it recently — flashing by like a dragonfly but “bigger than anything that would come by here.” His suspicions only grew when he heard a low-pitched buzzing sound — first outside, and then again inside his shop, where he had gone to fetch a tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: To Hold Police Accountable, Ax the Arbitrators
description: Communities should have the power to fire abusive officers. But that power often rests with an obscure group of unelected labor arbitrators.
content: Since the death of George Floyd sparked a wave of national protests, at least 42 of the 50 largest cities in the country have adopted new rules aimed at curbing abuses by the police, according to a tally by Samuel Walker, an expert on police accountability who is affiliated with the University of Nebraska Omaha. From May through August, 15 cities banned chokeholds. A dozen passed “duty-to-intervene” statutes, requiring police officers to act if they see a fellow officer endanger a civilian. Still others banned so-called “no knock” warrants or changed policies related to the use of force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: McConnell Delays Senate’s Return as a Third Senator Falls Ill
description: Senator Mitch McConnell postponed the Senate’s return for two weeks but said lawmakers would continue confirmation hearings as planned.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said on Saturday that the Senate would not meet as planned next week after three senators tested positive for the coronavirus, even as he pledged to press ahead to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Why Did Hundreds of Thousands of Women Drop Out of the Workforce?
description: In some families buckling under the caregiving burden, the lower wage earner is leaving the workforce. Usually that’s the wife.
content: — Stefania Albanesi, an economics professor at the University of Pittsburgh
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanam Yar
title: Lili Reinhart Is Just Being Honest
description: The “Riverdale” star is reluctant to call herself an activist. But she has a lot to say and isn’t afraid to do so.
content: Lili Reinhart has been outspoken for almost as long as she’s been famous. The star of the popular teen soap “Riverdale” has openly discussed her struggles with anxiety, depression and body dysmorphia. She has also been vocal about women’s reproductive rights, white privilege, her disapproval of President Trump and the public’s undying fascination with Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeneen Interlandi
title: Now the President and Frontline Workers Have Something in Common
description: The difference is not all frontline workers can protect themselves on the job. The coronavirus race gap, explained.
content: Most of the women in Maria Jose Bastias’s English language class, at Mujeres Unidas y Activas, a nonprofit in San Francisco, did not know that they could get a coronavirus test without health insurance, or that they were legally entitled to paid sick leave if they contracted the virus, regardless of their immigration status. They worked grueling hours at menial jobs that offered little security; it had not occurred to many of them to even ask about such benefits, let alone to expect them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: The Short Tenure and Abrupt Ouster of Banking’s Sole Black C.E.O.
description: Tidjane Thiam made Credit Suisse profitable again. But the Swiss rejected him as an outsider, and a sudden scandal took him down.
content: Last November, Urs Rohner, the chairman of the board of Credit Suisse, had a party at a Zurich restaurant to celebrate his 60th birthday. Among the scores of friends, family and business associates who gathered, attendees say, there was a single Black guest: Tidjane Thiam, the bank’s chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Attorney General Barr will not self-quarantine, despite possible exposure to the coronavirus.
description: He attended a reception for Amy Coney Barrett, an event where several other attendees later tested positive.
content: Attorney General William P. Barr, the nation’s top law enforcement officer, has decided not to self-quarantine, despite potential prolonged exposure to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Hospitalized With Coronavirus
description: The president was flown to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, where officials said he would stay for several days. Aides said Mr. Trump was experiencing coughing, congestion and fever, symptoms that worsened through the day.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump was hospitalized on Friday evening after learning he had the coronavirus and experiencing what aides called coughing, congestion and fever, throwing the nation’s leadership into uncertainty and destabilizing an already volatile campaign only 32 days before the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: Trump Tests Positive for Coronavirus: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: A year of surprises had its biggest one yet — a coronavirus diagnosis for President Trump that has thrown the White House and the November presidential race into flux.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: ‘Fifth Girl’ in 1963 Church Bombing Gets an Apology From Alabama’s Governor
description: Gov. Kay Ivey offered to have state officials meet with lawyers for a maimed survivor of an infamous racist attack in Birmingham to discuss restitution for an “egregious injustice.”
content: Sarah Collins Rudolph had appealed to local and state leaders in Alabama for years, asking for some form of restitution, after the 1963 bombing of the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala. The explosion blinded her right eye, killed her sister and three other girls, and started a struggle with injuries and trauma that weighs on Ms. Rudolph to this day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Pandemic Depression Is Over. The Pandemic Recession Has Just Begun.
description: Signs of a slower, grinding recovery sure look familiar.
content: There is a straightforward narrative of the economy in 2020: The world shut down in the spring because of the coronavirus pandemic, causing an economic collapse without modern precedent. A sharp recovery began in May as businesses reopened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: A White House Long in Denial Confronts Reality
description: The infections were a byproduct, former aides said, of the recklessness and top-down culture of fear that President Trump created at the White House and throughout his administration.
content: WASHINGTON — As America locked down this spring during the worst pandemic in a century, inside the Trump White House there was the usual defiance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: A sudden reversal of fortune weighs on an already strained Trump campaign.
description: Since March, some of President Trump’s advisers had whispered that there could come a day when the president tested positive for the coronavirus. But it was not an eventuality anyone planned for.
content: Since March, some of President Trump’s advisers had whispered that there could come a day when the president tested positive for the coronavirus. But it was not an eventuality anyone planned for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Belgium Arrests 3 Men Suspected of Involvement in Rwandan Genocide
description: The men, whose identities were not made public, are charged with serious abuse of human rights.
content: LONDON — Three men suspected of involvement in the 1994 Rwanda genocide were arrested in Belgium this week, according to the Belgian authorities, the latest in a series of captures linked to the 100-day blood bath in which as many as one million people were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron and Ken Belson
title: Patriots-Chiefs Game Postponed After Positive Coronavirus Tests on Both Teams
description: Cam Newton was reportedly among those who tested positive. Sunday’s game will be rescheduled to Monday or Tuesday, the N.F.L. said.
content: The N.F.L. has postponed Sunday’s highly anticipated game between the New England Patriots and the Kansas City Chiefs to Monday or Tuesday after Cam Newton, the Patriots’ star quarterback, and the practice squad quarterback on the Chiefs tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Ben Casselman and Gillian Friedman
title: Workers Face Permanent Job Losses as the Virus Persists
description: Soon, a wave of people will have been out of work for more than six months, the threshold for long-term unemployment.
content: The United States economy is facing a tidal wave of long-term unemployment as millions of people who lost jobs early in the pandemic remain out of work six months later and job losses increasingly turn permanent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump’s diagnosis imperils a quick Supreme Court confirmation timeline.
description: A coronavirus outbreak that infected President Trump and spread to the Senate has thrown a fresh element of uncertainty into the politically fraught fight over installing Judge Amy Coney Barrett on the Supreme Court before Election Day, with Republicans vowing to press ahead and Democrats insisting on a pause.
content: A coronavirus outbreak that infected President Trump and spread to the Senate has thrown a fresh element of uncertainty into the politically fraught fight over installing Judge Amy Coney Barrett on the Supreme Court before Election Day, with Republicans vowing to press ahead and Democrats insisting on a pause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
title: With Trump Sidelined, His Campaign Promises MAGA as Usual
description: A campaign whose fund-raising, events and messaging have all been driven by President Trump says it will stay the course while he’s off the campaign trail.
content: The Trump campaign is not changing its advertising or messaging, even with the candidate in the hospital. The political operation is not bereft of leaders; the campaign manager is still helping run things from afar after testing positive for the virus. Advisers are not showing any evidence of worry, despite public polls showing President Trump still behind in key states he won in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Battling Wildfire and Pandemic, Ukraine Faces a New Foe: Landmines
description: The blaze is setting off mines and other ordnance littering the war zone in eastern Ukraine, hampering already dangerous firefighting and evacuation efforts.
content: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — A wildfire burning out of control in the war zone in eastern Ukraine is setting off land mines in a buffer area between government forces and Russian-backed separatists, complicating the already dangerous work of fire crews facing hot, dry and windy conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Jobs Gains Lose Momentum as Promising Recovery Stalls
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 3, 2020.
content: “It’s disturbing that we’re seeing such a dramatic slowdown in employment gains as we head into the fall. This is a red flag. We need aid now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Swiss Skydiver, With a Last-Minute Jockey, Wins the Preakness Stakes
description: Robby Albarado was called in late to ride Swiss Skydiver, who became the sixth filly to win the race and the first to do so since 2009.
content: Sometimes the wrong jockey gets on the right horse. Ask Robby Albarado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Germany’s Far Right Reunified, Too, Making It Much Stronger
description: Thirty years after Germany came back together, the former East has become the stronghold of a once-marginalized movement that now sits in Parliament.
content: BERLIN — They called him the “Führer of Berlin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Lincoln Has Another Lesson for Trump
description: The essence of the American idea is unity under the law, through and despite difference.
content: “With malice toward none; with charity for all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 French Open: What to Watch on Saturday
description: While Sofia Kenin and Novak Djokovic occupy Philippe Chatrier Court, some hotly contested matches will enliven the third round on the smaller stadium courts.
content: How to watch: 5 a.m. to noon on Tennis Channel; streaming on the Tennis Channel app and, starting at 11 a.m., on Peacock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Following Falsehoods: A Reporter’s Approach on QAnon
description: Kevin Roose, a Times tech columnist, has watched the baseless conspiracy theory grow from fringe internet subculture to mass movement, carefully calibrating his coverage along the way.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In Nagorno-Karabakh, New Risks in an Old Ethnic Conflict
description: Fighting in and around the breakaway enclave shows signs that a local ethnic dispute is spiraling into a regional conflict.
content: MOSCOW — Fighting broke out a week ago in Nagorno-Karabakh, a breakaway region in Azerbaijan with an Armenian majority, setting off alarms about the risks of a wider war that might draw in Russia, Turkey and Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Marching Bands
description: Brendan Emmett Quigley orders us into shapes.
content: MARCHING BANDS — Here we have one of those variety puzzles that draws elements from others that we solve, when you stop to think about it. I’m reminded of the cryptic, where our perception of hidden words has been honed, and the diagramless, where you need to keep track of where to start and end entries so they don’t screw up your unnumbered grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Peter Baker
title: Trump says he feels better, but his chief of staff says he is ‘still not on a clear path to a full recovery.’
description: President Trump’s vital signs were “very concerning” over the last day and he is not out of danger, the White House chief of staff said on Saturday, contradicting a rosier picture painted by the president’s doctors on television just minutes before.
content: President Trump’s vital signs were “very concerning” over the last day and he is not out of danger, the White House chief of staff said on Saturday, contradicting a rosier picture painted by the president’s doctors on television just minutes before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! I’d Like to Ride the Train. Is it Safe?
description: Our columnist finds that rail companies, both regional systems and Amtrak, are undertaking massive coronavirus efforts. But they can’t thoroughly disinfect every seat in every train at every station.
content: I’ve been hesitant to take a train during the pandemic because I have concerns about safety. I live in Philadelphia, which means that by the time I board, the train has already picked up new passengers at several other stops. What are rail companies like Amtrak doing to adjust to Covid-19, and what can passengers do to stay healthy while traveling? Ann
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Obama offers prayers for Trump, while the president’s campaign insults Obama in a fund-raising letter.
description: Former President Barack Obama and Senator Kamala Harris of California offered their prayers to President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, on Friday evening, colliding with the timing of an emailed fund-raising appeal from the Trump campaign.
content: Former President Barack Obama and Senator Kamala Harris of California offered their prayers to President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, on Friday evening, colliding with the timing of an emailed fund-raising appeal from the Trump campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Trump’s Diagnosis Is a Wake-Up Call for Americans
description: Forget the snark. Just wear a mask.
content: The first thing to say is simple: Best wishes to President Trump and the first lady for a speedy recovery from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Annie Karni
title: Pence Tests Negative for Virus and Will Debate With Harris Next Week
description: With President Trump’s positive coronavirus test, Vice President Mike Pence will take on a more prominent campaign role and represent him at events.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence, the first in line to occupy the Oval Office if President Trump becomes too ill to carry out his duties, tested negative for the coronavirus on Friday and planned to resume campaign appearances, including at the vice-presidential debate on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: ‘They Chose to Stay Open and Fight’
description: Restaurant workers share their struggles since the pandemic.
content: For those working in the restaurant industry, “Every day is a negotiation: of labor costs, food costs, rent, insurance, health inspections, and the art and craft of creating an experience special enough to keep people coming through the doors,” writes Priya Krishna in her Op-Ed, “How to Save Restaurants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: The U.S. and Europe lag on implementing an essential weapon against the virus: contact tracing.
description: Experts have warned that fall will be a uniquely challenging time for combating the pandemic, yet one of the most essential tools for stemming the spread of the coronavirus still has not been widely deployed in the United States and Europe.
content: Experts have warned that fall will be a uniquely challenging time for combating the pandemic, yet one of the most essential tools for stemming the spread of the coronavirus still has not been widely deployed in the United States and Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: This One-Pan Orzo With Feta Is #1
description: The most popular recipes of the week.
content: This weekend make Melissa Clark’s comforting vegetarian dish (above), butternut squash and lentils with pomegranate molasses and honey dressing, or an heirloom tomato tart from Vallery Lomas. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: As Trump’s Diagnosis Spooks G.O.P., Pelosi Projects Optimism on Stimulus Deal
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the president’s positive coronavirus test could change the dynamic and produce an agreement on additional pandemic relief, but a compromise remained elusive.
content: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California on Friday suggested that President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis could help to break a stalemate over a stimulus package to counter the economic toll of the pandemic, even as she remained far from an agreement with the administration on the contours of a bipartisan compromise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Christina Morales
title: What to Know About Sean Conley, the White House Physician
description: Dr. Conley, who was appointed as President Trump’s physician in 2018, is a doctor of osteopathic medicine.
content: As President Trump remains hospitalized at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center after testing positive for the coronavirus, one doctor is at the center of his treatment: Sean P. Conley, the White House physician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Maddie McGarvey
title: Why a Pro-Trump Town No Longer Sees Him as a Rescuer
description: Portsmouth, Ohio, was facing hard times when our reporter spent a week there leading up to Election Day 2016. She went back to find the town rebounding, and loyal to President Trump. But its residents no longer tie their fortunes to him.
content: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio — It was right around 10 p.m. at Buffalo Wild Wings on Scioto Trail when the needle swung from Hillary Clinton to Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: 74 and Overweight, Trump Faces Extra Risks From ‘a Very Sneaky Virus’
description: The president has boasted of his health and is sure to receive the best possible care, but he carries a number of risk factors as he begins his battle with Covid-19.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump, like many men in their 70s, has mild heart disease. He takes a statin drug to treat high cholesterol and aspirin to prevent heart attacks. And at 244 pounds in a health summary released in June, he has crossed the line into obesity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: Despite Crises, India Fixes Its Gaze on a Bollywood Tragedy
description: Covid-19 is rippling through the country. The economy is reeling. But for many Indians, an actor’s death and the investigation that followed are a bigger story.
content: NEW DELHI — A rising young movie star meets a tragic end. His family blames his death on his glamorous girlfriend. As she sits in jail, her friends proclaiming her innocence, the police hint at a shadowy network of money laundering and illegal drugs deep within the world of show business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With Patchwork Pitching, the Padres Turn Another Page
description: To win their first postseason series in 14 seasons, San Diego relied on nine different pitchers and some thrilling young stars to dispatch the Cardinals.
content: When the San Diego Padres announced their first-round playoff roster Wednesday, it was hard not to look and think: Well, it was fun while it lasted. There were 14 pitchers among the 28 names, but not Mike Clevinger or Dinelson Lamet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Nicholas Fandos, Catie Edmondson, Lisa Lerer, Lauren Wolfe and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Two senators on the Judiciary Committee test positive, raising questions about the timing of Barrett’s confirmation hearings.
description: Two Republican senators on the pivotal Judiciary Committee have tested positive for the coronavirus after attending White House events last week announcing President Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, throwing the future of her Supreme Court confirmation hearings into question.
content: Two Republican senators on the pivotal Judiciary Committee have tested positive for the coronavirus after attending White House events last week announcing President Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, throwing the future of her Supreme Court confirmation hearings into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: If Commercial Gyms Can Reopen, Why Can’t the One in My Building?
description: State guidelines do not differentiate between stand-alone gyms and those inside residential buildings, which can make things tough for condos and co-ops.
content: Q: Commercial gyms have reopened in New York City, but my condo’s gym remains closed, and the managing agent says it will remain that way for the foreseeable future because the building doesn’t have the staff or resources to comply with city guidelines. Are gyms in residential buildings really held to the same standard as commercial gyms? Couldn’t the building devise sensible safety measures, like limiting use to one household at a time, or letting residents sign a liability waiver?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Setter’s Activity
description: Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson make quite a racket on a Saturday.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a fun, gritty solve by a couple of serial and nonmonagamous collaborators, Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson. I don’t think that I can tell between single and double-byline puzzles with any accuracy, but I assume that co-construction is an amiable affair practiced mainly by amiable folk, so I’m always predisposed to like these puzzles when I notice their origin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: After 30 Years, East and West Germans Wonder: How United Are We?
description: With Germany now an established, reunified democracy, it is taking stock of what is working and what still needs work, especially as the economy continues to lag in the former East.
content: BERLIN — Robert Hellmundt was born in East Germany in 1989, the year that the Berlin Wall fell. Some two decades later, he decided to quit the East after graduating from university, like so many of his generation looking for brighter futures, and move to the capital of a reunified Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Monica Davey
title: Covid-19 Continues Its Ever-Changing Onslaught on the U.S.
description: The infection of President Trump and some of his top associates makes clear that the country is still in the throes of the pandemic.
content: Covid-19 has proved itself an unpredictable and ever-changing threat. As President Trump and some of his allies and associates test positive for the coronavirus, the number of new cases reported each day across the United States has been slowly rising. The nation’s response has been uneven and inconsistent. Here is where the country is now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu and Jonathan Corum
title: Charting a Coronavirus Infection
description: Following the course of a typical Covid-19 case.
content: Following the course of a typical Covid-19 case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Lazaro Gamio, Lauren Leatherby, Robin Stein and Christiaan Triebert
title: Inside the White House Event Now Under Covid Scrutiny
description: Since a Sept. 26 celebration for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, at least seven attendees have tested positive for the virus.
content: Since a Sept. 26 celebration for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, at least seven attendees have tested positive for the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Trump’s Coronavirus Diagnosis Is a ‘Bracing Reminder,’ Biden Says
description: During a speech in Grand Rapids, Mich., Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, offered prayers for President Trump and the first lady.
content: During a speech in Grand Rapids, Mich., Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, offered prayers for President Trump and the first lady.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘I Feel Much Better Now,’ Trump Says
description: President Trump released a video update on his health from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. The message came after a day of confusing reports.
content: President Trump released a video update on his health from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. The message came after a day of confusing reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Simon Johnson
title: While You Were Sleeping
description: How we turned a late-night debate into an early-morning show. Plus: A special episode, “The Pandemic Reaches the President.”
content: This week, millions of Americans fell asleep after the first presidential debate ended. By the time they woke up on Wednesday, we had published a full episode breaking down the chaos of the event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Profits and Social Responsibility: Revisiting Milton Friedman
description: Fifty years after publication of his influential manifesto on free-market capitalism, readers discuss whether profits should be a corporation’s top priority.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 3, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 3, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about the precautions that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is taking to protect himself from the coronavirus misspelled the surname of Brazil’s president. He is Jair Bolsonaro, not Jair Balsonaro.
source.name: The New York Times
